etymologies: Middle English: from Middle Dutch, Middle Low German schūren, from Old French escurer, from late Latin excurare ‘clean (off)’, from ex- ‘away’ + curare ‘to clean’

definitions: clean or brighten the surface of (something) by rubbing it hard, typically with an abrasive or detergent
shortDefinitions: clean or brighten surface of something by rubbing it hard

definitions: remove (dirt or unwanted matter) by rubbing with an abrasive or detergent

examples.text: use an electric toothbrush to scour off plaque
I've spent all day mopping and scouring

shortDefinitions: remove dirt or unwanted matter by scouring

definitions: (of water or a watercourse) make (a channel or pool) by flowing forcefully over something and removing soil or rock

examples.text: a stream came crashing through a narrow cavern to scour out a round pool below

shortDefinitions: make channel or pool by flowing quickly over something and removing soil or rock

examples.text: he immediately proceeded to scour him with the most potent medicines

definitions: the action of scouring or the state of being scoured, especially by swift-flowing water

examples.text: the scour of the tide may cause lateral erosion

shortDefinitions: action of scouring or state of being scoured

definitions: an act of rubbing something hard to clean or brighten it

examples.text: give the floor a good scour

shortDefinitions: act of rubbing something hard to clean or brighten it

definitions: diarrhea in livestock, especially cattle and pigs.

etymologies: late Middle English: related to obsolete scour ‘moving hastily’, of unknown origin

definitions: subject (a place, text, etc.) to a thorough search in order to locate something

examples.text: David scoured each newspaper for an article on the murder

shortDefinitions: subject (place, text, etc.) to thorough search

definitions: move rapidly in a particular direction, especially in search or pursuit of someone or something

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

synonyms.text: go through with a fine-tooth comb
